summary: Both excerpts establish the compliance and reporting obligations for EBA guidelines, requiring competent authorities and financial institutions to make every effort to comply. Specifically, both state that competent authorities must notify the EBA of their compliance status or reasons for non-compliance, and that these notifications will be published.

overlaps.filename1: Final Guidelines on Accounting for Expected Credit Losses (EBA-GL-2017-06).di_page_12.json
overlaps.excerpt1: 1. This document contains guidelines issued pursuant to Article 16 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 15. In accordance with Article 16(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010, competent authorities and financial institutions must make every effort to comply with the guidelines. 2. Guidelines set the EBA view of appropriate supervisory practices within the European System of Financial Supervision (ESFS) or of how Union law should be applied in a particular area. Competent authorities as defined in Article 4(2) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 to whom guidelines apply should comply by incorporating them into their practices as appropriate (e.g. by amending their legal framework or their supervisory processes), including where guidelines are directed primarily at institutions. Reporting requirements 3. According to Article 16(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010, competent authorities must notify the EBA as to whether they comply or intend to comply with these guidelines, or otherwise with reasons for non-compliance, by ([dd.mm.yyyy]). In the absence of any notification by this deadline, competent authorities will be considered by the EBA to be non- compliant. Notifications should be sent by submitting the form available on the EBA website to compliance@eba.europa.eu with the reference 'EBA/GL/2017/06'. Notifications should be submitted by persons with appropriate authority to report compliance on behalf of their competent authorities. Any change in the status of compliance must also be reported to the EBA. 4. Notifications will be published on the EBA website, in line with Article 16(3).
overlaps.filename2: Final Guidelines on management of non-performing and forborne exposures.di_page_13.json
overlaps.excerpt2: 1. This document contains guidelines issued pursuant to Article 16 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010. 7 In accordance with Article 16(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010, competent authorities and credit institutions must make every effort to comply with the guidelines. 2. Guidelines set out the EBA's view of appropriate supervisory practices within the European System of Financial Supervision or of how Union law should be applied in a particular area. Competent authorities as defined in Article 4(2) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 to which guidelines apply should comply by incorporating them into their practices as appropriate (e.g. by amending their legal framework or their supervisory processes), including where guidelines are directed primarily at institutions. Reporting requirements 3. In accordance with Article 16(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010, competent authorities must notify the EBA that they comply or intend to comply with these guidelines, or otherwise give reasons for non-compliance, by ([dd.mm.yyyy]). In the absence of any notification by this deadline, competent authorities will be considered by the EBA to be non-compliant. Notifications should be sent by submitting the form available on the EBA website to compliance@eba.europa.eu with the reference 'EBA/GL/201x/xx'. Notifications should be submitted by persons with appropriate authority to report compliance on behalf of their competent authorities. Any change in the status of compliance must also be reported to the EBA. 4. Notifications will be published on the EBA website, in line with Article 16(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010.
overlaps.explanation: Both excerpts define the status and reporting requirements for EBA guidelines under Article 16(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010. They both state that competent authorities and financial institutions must make every effort to comply, that competent authorities must notify the EBA of their compliance status by a specified deadline, and that these notifications will be published. The language used is almost identical, establishing the same obligations for the same actors in the same functional context.

Competent authorities as defined in Article 4(2) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 to whom guidelines apply should comply by incorporating them into their practices as appropriate (e.g. by amending their legal framework or their supervisory processes), including where guidelines are directed primarily at institutions. overlaps.excerpt2: 1. This document contains Guidelines issued pursuant to Article 16 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010.7 In accordance with Article 16(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010, competent authorities and financial institutions must make every effort to comply with the Guidelines. 2. Guidelines set the EBA view of appropriate supervisory practices within the European System of Financial Supervision or of how Union law should be applied in a particular area. Competent authorities as defined in Article 4(2) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 to whom Guidelines apply should comply by incorporating them into their practices as appropriate (e.g., by amending their legal framework or their supervisory processes), including where Guidelines are directed primarily at institutions. Reporting requirements 3. According to Article 16(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010, competent authorities must notify the EBA as to whether they comply or intend to comply with these Guidelines, or otherwise with reasons for non-compliance, by 02.05.2023. In the absence of any notification by this deadline, competent authorities will be considered by the EBA to be non- compliant. Notifications should be sent by submitting the form available on the EBA website with the reference 'EBA/GL/2022/14'. Notifications should be submitted by persons with appropriate authority to report compliance on behalf of their competent authorities. Any change in the status of compliance must also be reported to EBA. 4. Notifications will be published on the EBA website, in line with Article 16(3).
overlaps.explanation: Both excerpts outline the identical compliance and reporting obligations for EBA guidelines under Article 16(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010. They both require competent authorities and financial institutions to make every effort to comply and mandate competent authorities to notify the EBA of their compliance status. The only difference is the specific deadline and guideline reference number, which is expected as they pertain to different guidelines, but the underlying obligation and procedure are the same.

overlaps.filename2: Guidelines on MLTF risk management and access to financial services.di_page_8.json
overlaps.excerpt2: 1. This document contains guidelines issued pursuant to Article 16 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/20105. In accordance with Article 16(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010, competent authorities and credit and financial institutions must make every effort to comply with the guidelines. 2. Guidelines set the EBA view of appropriate supervisory practices within the European Sys- tem of Financial Supervision or of how Union law should be applied in a particular area. Competent authorities as defined in Article 4(2) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 to whom guidelines apply should comply by incorporating them into their practices as appropriate (e.g. by amending their legal framework or their supervisory processes), including where guidelines are directed primarily at institutions. Reporting requirements 3. According to Article 16(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010, competent authorities must notify the EBA as to whether they comply or intend to comply with these guidelines, or otherwise with reasons for non-compliance, by [dd.mm.yyyy]. In the absence of any notifi- cation by this deadline, competent authorities will be considered by the EBA to be non- compliant. Notifications should be sent by submitting the form available on the EBA web- site with the reference 'EBA/GL/2023/04'. Notifications should be submitted by persons with appropriate authority to report compliance on behalf of their competent authorities. Any change in the status of compliance must also be reported to EBA. 4. Notifications will be published on the EBA website, in line with Article 16(3).
overlaps.explanation: Both excerpts precisely define the compliance and reporting obligations for EBA guidelines under Article 16(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010. They mandate that competent authorities and financial institutions make every effort to comply, and require competent authorities to notify the EBA of their compliance status. While the specific deadline and guideline reference differ due to being different guidelines, the core regulatory subject, actors, actions, and functional context regarding EBA guideline compliance and reporting are identical.
